title: The Asian Origins of Global Capitalism: European Factories in the Indian Ocean, 1500-1800
descriptions:
Here is a 293-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Asian Origins of Global Capitalism: European Factories in the Indian Ocean, 1500-1800

This five-year project seeks to fundamentally recast our understanding of the origins of modern industrial capitalism by examining the pivotal role of Asian ports and European East India companies in shaping global trade and economic dynamism between 1500 and 1800. Through an innovative spatial theory of capitalist development, our research will map the intercontinental movement of goods, people, and information, highlighting the interactive roles of European and local merchants in imperial trading centers. By investigating over 150 factories as key sites of economic activity, we will challenge prevailing narratives of global economic change and capitalism.

Our project integrates large archival repositories and foster collaborations globally, ensuring a decolonized and nuanced understanding of the history of capitalism. We will explore the economic activities in imperial trading centers, examining the factors that contributed to the rise of global capitalism. By doing so, we will contribute to the New History of Capitalism, a burgeoning field that seeks to rebalance the dominant Eurocentric perspective on economic development.

Ultimately, this project aims to provide a more comprehensive and inclusive understanding of the origins of global capitalism, highlighting the critical role of Asian ports and European East India companies in shaping the modern economic landscape. By reframing the narrative of global economic change, we will offer a more accurate and multifaceted understanding of the complex historical processes that have shaped our globalized world.

Title: The Asian Origins of Global Capitalism: European Factories in the Indian Ocean, 1500-1800

This five-year project reexamines the origins of modern industrial capitalism by shifting the focus from European metropoles to Asian ports and the global trade networks that connected them. Through an in-depth analysis of over 150 European East India companies' factories in the Indian Ocean region between 1500 and 1800, this research aims to recast the narrative of global economic change and capitalism. By integrating large archival repositories and collaborating with scholars globally, this project will map the intercontinental movement of goods, people, and information, revealing the interactive roles of European and local merchants in imperial trading centers.

The project's central argument is that the spatial dynamics of these factories, situated at the intersection of Asian and European trade networks, played a crucial role in shaping the development of modern capitalism. By exploring the economic activities in these factories, this research will contribute to the New History of Capitalism and decolonize the history of capitalism by highlighting the agency of non-European actors. The project's findings will challenge prevailing Eurocentric narratives of capitalist development, offering a more nuanced understanding of the complex, interconnected processes that shaped the global economy. Ultimately, this project will provide a new spatial theory of capitalist development, highlighting the significance of Asian ports and trade networks in the emergence of modern industrial capitalism.
